questions.question: What is a network baseline?
questions.explanation: Baseline: baseline metrics. Purpose: identify abnormal behavior. Data: latency, packet loss, bandwidth. Collection: periodic. Benefit: anomaly detection. Importance: troubleshooting foundation.

questions.question: What is root cause analysis?
questions.explanation: Analysis: systematically find cause. Method: trace symptoms to source. Tools: logs, monitoring. Approach: methodical investigation. Benefit: proper fix. Importance: problem solving.

questions.question: What is the OSI model troubleshooting?
questions.explanation: Approach: start layer 1 (physical). Check: each layer. Benefit: systematic. Example: check cables, then data link. Tools: vary by layer. Importance: structured approach.

questions.question: What is a network sniffer
questions.explanation: Sniffer: listens to traffic. Purpose: analysis, troubleshooting. Passive: no interference. Tools: Wireshark, tcpdump. Limitation: local traffic only. Importance: observation tool.

questions.question: What is port mirroring?
questions.explanation: Mirroring: duplicate traffic. Purpose: monitoring. Active: uses switch resources. Configuration: SPAN (Cisco). Limitation: performance impact. Importance: monitoring technique.

questions.question: What is link aggregation?
questions.explanation: Aggregation: parallel links. Benefit: bandwidth increase, redundancy. Technology: LAG, LACP. Configuration: switch. Purpose: performance, availability. Importance: advanced technique.

questions.question: What is a network loop?
questions.explanation: Loop: packets circle endlessly. Cause: redundant connections without blocking. Result: broadcast storm. Solution: STP. Prevention: careful topology. Importance: network issue.

questions.question: What is a broadcast storm?
questions.explanation: Storm: broadcasts propagate. Cause: network loop. Effect: network saturation. Solution: STP, VLAN. Prevention: topology. Importance: serious problem.

questions.question: What is the three-way handshake?
questions.explanation: Handshake: SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK. Purpose: establish connection. Sequence: three packets. Flags: set appropriately. Termination: FIN-ACK. Importance: connection fundamental.

questions.question: What is MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit)?
questions.explanation: MTU: typically 1500 bytes. Ethernet: standard size. Jumbo: 9000 bytes possible. Path: MTU varies. Discovery: PMTUD. Impact: fragmentation. Importance: performance tuning.
